Louisville women clobber No. 22 Iowa, 86-52

Louisville women clobber No. 22 Iowa, 86-52

Josh Cook, Special to The Courier-Journal 7:41 a.m. EST December 5, 2014

Louisville's Myisha Hines-Allen fights Iowa's Whitney Jennings for the rebound. Dec. 4, 2014(Photo: Scott Utterback/The C-J)

42 CONNECT 11 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

One of Thursday night's marquee matchups of the women's ACC/Big Ten Challenge was a mismatch.

The University of Louisville obliterated Iowa 86-52 in a battle between two ranked teams at the KFC Yum! Center. Five Cardinals scored in double figures - led by senior Sara Hammond's season-high 19 points - to lead U of L to its eighth consecutive win to start the season.

Louisville, which is No. 7 in both national polls, shot 53 percent from the field and outscored Iowa 58-32 in the paint. Meanwhile the Cards held the Hawkeyes (6-2), who are No. 19 in the USA Today Coaches Poll and No. 22 in the Associated Press Top 25, to 30.4 percent shooting - including 5.9 from 3-point range. Iowa, which entered second nationally in long-range shooting (43.8 percent), was just 1 for 17 from downtown.

"I thought we played extremely well," U of L coach Jeff Walz said. "I thought we followed the scouting report, I thought we played pretty darn hard for 40 minutes...I was really proud of how we defended."

Louisville's Coach Walz talks after Iowa win.

Freshman forward Myisha Hines-Allen added 16 points - all in the first half - and a team-high tying seven rebounds for the Cards, who never trailed and built a 46-23 halftime lead.

U of L, which beat Iowa 83-53 last year in the second round of the NCAA Tournament, used first-half runs of 12-2 and 12-0 to take control early.

"We were just ready to bring the energy and ready to throw the first punch because we knew what we did to them last year," Hammond said.

Hammond tallied six points in the first of those spurts, helping the Cards go from a 2-2 tie to 14-2 lead. Hines-Allen then scored five in the second surge, which help grow Louisville's lead to 26-9.

MORE: 'M and M' freshmen lead Louisville women to W's

The highlight of the first half came when UofL senior guard Bria Smith stuffed Whitney Jennings' 3-point attempt, then raced to the other end for a layin, giving the Cards a 20-point lead (35-15).

In addition to Hines-Allen's 16, Hammond - who went scoreless in last year's NCAA Tournament game against the Hawkeyes - tallied 12 in the first half.

The Cards shot 52.8 percent (19 for 36), most on inside baskets as they outscored Iowa 28-10 in the paint, in the first 20 minutes while holding the Hawkeyes to 23.7 percent (9 for 38). Iowa, which was picked third in the Big Ten preseason poll, was 1 for 11 (9.1 percent) from 3-point range.

The second half was more of the same.

    Last SlideNext Slide

    Everything, it seemed, was going in for the Cards. After receiving a nice pass from Mariya Moore underneath the basket Emmonnie Henderson was bumped and tossed up an off-balance shot that - to the Hawkeyes' chagrin and the crowd's delight - went in. That pushed Louisville's lead to 71-38 with just under 10 minutes to play.

    The Cards, who finished 35 for 66 from the field, cruised from there. On the flip side, Iowa was only 21 for 69.

    Moore tallied 12 points and game-highs in assists (six) and steals (four) while Henderson and Smith added 10 points and seven rebounds apiece.

    The Cards next host archrival, and 13th-ranked, Kentucky at 2 p.m. Sunday.

    "I can't wait for the game, honestly, because I know it's going to be a soldout crowd," Hines-Allen said.

    Louisville's two top scores, Sara Hammond (19 points) and Myisha Hines-Allen (16 points) talk about the Cards' big win over Iowa and the upcoming game versus rival Kentucky.
